page.title: 02The Landscape (2)
page.content: Hidden among the fields are about 30 buildings shown to have been here on the 1840 Tithe Map. Most were formerly timber-framed; the local clay, though cold, heavy and difficult to cultivate produces magnificent oak trees whose timbers were always much in demand for house and ship-building. Willow and hazel were used with clay for wattle and daub. Large barns were also built this way. A few stone-built houses use winklestone in their walls or floors. Some roofs are of fine Horsham slabs, weathered to plum grey colour; others are of old tiles. There appear to be no examples remaining of a thatch. Many fine old farmhouses have been sold away from the actual farms. This is a popular area for businessmen who wish to live within reach of London or Gatwick Airport and who can afford to buy and maintain such expensive homes.
